unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Constructing a $2$-sample Mean Interval: Dunkin Bucks
question_text:
Dunkin Bucks is interested in the number of cups of coffee their adults customers drink per day compared with their teenage customers. Dunkin Bucks randomly selects $75$ adults and $75$ teenagers and asks them: "How many cups of coffee do you drink?" The resulting data is below:
Which of the following represents a $95\%$ confidence interval for the difference in the average number of cups of coffee drunk per day between Dunkin Bucks adult customers and teenage customers?
Which of the following represents a $95\%$ confidence interval for the difference in the average number of cups of coffee drunk per day between Dunkin Bucks adult customers and teenage customers?
solution:
This question deals with a $2$-sample $t$-interval for means. This is a $t$-interval and not a $z$-interval because we don't know the standard deviation of the population. Remember the phrase, "Mr. T is mean." The formula for a two sample $t$-interval for means is:

$$(\overline { { x }_{ 1 } } -\overline { { x }_{ 2 } } )\pm { { t }_{ d.o.f. } }\cdot \sqrt { \dfrac { { { (s }_{ 1 } })^{ 2 } }{ { n }_{ 1 } } +\dfrac { { { (s }_{ 2 } })^{ 2 } }{ { n }_{ 2 } } }$$

To find the critical value, in this case, is difficult. You can run the interval test on your calculator to get the D.O.F., which in this case $108.82$. Then, do InvT$(.975,108.82)$, and that will give you the critical value of $1.982$. The reason for $.975$ or $97.5\%$ is because InvT represents the area to the left. The $95\%$ is the central area and you must add the $2.5\%$ on the remaining left tail. This will give $97.5\%$.

An easier way is to approximate and look at the $t$-distribution table. Find where $75$ D.O.F. and $95\%$ confidence intersect, which in this case is $1.992$. $1.982$ is closer to $1.992$ than $1.96$.

Finally, you could always get the answer for the interval on your calculator. Then do the arithmetic out for the available choices and see which one matches.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect. When dealing with means, we are working with $t$-intervals and not $z$-intervals. The critical value in Choice 'A' is $1.96$, which is the critical value for $95\%$ confidence interval for $z$.

Choice 'B' is incorrect as well, because of the critical value and the standard error components are wrong.

Choice 'D' is incorrect, as the standard error component is wrong.

Choice 'E' is incorrect, as no critical value is given.
